resources.string: 30 Days of Polish Nature
European Roe Deer
Capreolus capreolus
The most numerous wild ungulate in Poland. Highly adaptable to forest, field, and mixed habitats.
Very abundant throughout all of Poland, present in almost every region.
Game Species. Population is stable and abundant (IUCN: Least Concern).
Red Fox
Vulpes vulpes
The most common and widespread wild canid, highly adaptable to rural and urban environments.
Present throughout all of Poland, with high population densities everywhere.
Common and abundant. Subject to hunting management (IUCN: Least Concern).
Wild Boar
Sus scrofa
Widespread ungulate known for rooting behavior, often found in forests and increasingly in urban fringe areas.
Common across the whole country, especially in eastern forests, with increasing presence near cities.
Game Species. Population is abundant and has been increasing (IUCN: Least Concern).
Red Deer
Cervus elaphus
One of the largest European deer species, typically found in large, dense forest complexes.
Widespread in forested areas, most numerous in northeastern forests (e.g., Białowieża) and southern mountains (Carpathians).
Game Species. Population is stable and well-managed (IUCN: Least Concern).
European Hare
Lepus europaeus
Common lagomorph of open fields and agricultural landscapes.
Widespread and abundant in lowlands, meadows, and cultivated fields across Poland.
Game Species. Population is considered stable, though subject to fluctuations (IUCN: Least Concern).
European Badger
Meles meles
Nocturnal carnivore living in complex underground burrows (setts). Highly adaptable omnivore.
Widespread across all of Poland, favoring woodlands, scrub, and sometimes park areas.
Game Species. Population is stable (IUCN: Least Concern).
Eurasian Beaver
Castor fiber
Europe\'s largest rodent, known for dam building. Successfully reintroduced and recovered.
Widely distributed near rivers, lakes, and streams throughout the country, with high densities in the northeast.
Partially Protected. Population is rapidly increasing and stable (IUCN: Least Concern).
Red Squirrel
Sciurus vulgaris
Arboreal rodent with tufted ears, common in coniferous and deciduous forests.
Widespread in most forested areas and urban parks across Poland.
Legally Protected. Population is stable (IUCN: Least Concern).
Bank Vole
Myodes glareolus
One of the most numerous small rodents, living in forests and dense vegetation.
Extremely widespread and abundant throughout all habitats in Poland.
Common. Not specifically protected (IUCN: Least Concern).
Common Vole
Microtus arvalis
A very common small rodent known for population explosions, especially in agricultural areas.
Extremely numerous in open fields, meadows, and agricultural land across the entire country.
Common. Not specifically protected (IUCN: Least Concern).
European Hedgehog
Erinaceus roumanicus
Common spiny mammal, often found in gardens, parks, and hedgerows near human settlements.
Widespread across all lowlands and lower elevations of Poland.
Legally Protected. Population status is generally stable but faces local threats (IUCN: Least Concern).
House Mouse
Mus musculus
Small omnivorous rodent, strongly associated with human habitation and buildings.
Present throughout all of Poland, wherever human structures provide shelter.
Common and abundant. Considered a pest species (IUCN: Least Concern).
Great Tit
Parus major
A common and recognizable small songbird of gardens and woodlands.
Extremely widespread and numerous in every type of habitat across Poland.
Common. Protected under general bird protection laws (IUCN: Least Concern).
Common Blackbird
Turdus merula
Familiar songbird; urban populations are often resident, while forest birds are migratory.
Widespread and very numerous throughout Poland, common in both forests and cities.
Common. Protected under general bird protection laws (IUCN: Least Concern).
Common Starling
Sturnus vulgaris
Known for its iridescent plumage and large, murmuring flocks during migration.
Widespread breeding bird across all of Poland, especially common near farmland and villages.
Common. Protected under general bird protection laws (IUCN: Least Concern).
Eurasian Magpie
Pica pica
Intelligent, bold, and highly visible corvid, often found close to human settlements.
Widespread and abundant across the entire country, thriving in urban and suburban areas.
Common. Protected under general bird protection laws (IUCN: Least Concern).
Common Wood Pigeon
Columba palumbus
The largest and most common pigeon species, often found in parks, gardens, and forests.
Extremely numerous in every region of Poland, particularly associated with farmlands and parks.
Common. Protected under general bird protection laws (IUCN: Least Concern).
White Stork
Ciconia ciconia
Iconic migratory bird, with Poland hosting the largest breeding population in the world.
Breeds across the entire country, but with significantly higher densities in the eastern and northeastern lowlands.
Legally **Protected** in Poland. Population is stable country-wide (IUCN: Least Concern).
Mallard
Anas platyrhynchos
The most common and familiar duck species, often semi-domesticated in parks.
Found on almost every body of water (rivers, lakes, ponds) across all of Poland.
Game Species. Population is abundant and stable (IUCN: Least Concern).
House Sparrow
Passer domesticus
A small, social bird strongly tied to human habitation.
Extremely common, found in nearly every village and city across the country.
Common. Protected under general bird protection laws (IUCN: Least Concern).
Eurasian Blue Tit
Cyanistes caeruleus
A common, small, and colorful songbird, often found feeding on bird feeders in winter.
Widespread and numerous in forests, parks, and gardens throughout Poland.
Common. Protected under general bird protection laws (IUCN: Least Concern).
Common Chaffinch
Fringilla coelebs
One of the most numerous bird species in Europe, easily identified by its song.
Very numerous breeding bird across all types of forests and woodlands in Poland.
Common. Protected under general bird protection laws (IUCN: Least Concern).
Common Buzzard
Buteo buteo
The most common raptor in Poland, often seen soaring above fields and forests.
Widespread throughout the entire country, often perching on roadside poles and trees.
Legally Protected. Population is stable and healthy (IUCN: Least Concern).
Hooded Crow
Corvus cornix
A highly intelligent corvid with a grey body and black head/wings, common in the north and east.
Widespread in the lowlands, especially in central, northern, and eastern Poland.
Common. Protected under general bird protection laws (IUCN: Least Concern).
Common Frog
Rana temporaria
The most widespread and common amphibian, spending most of its adult life on land.
Widespread throughout all of Poland, from lowlands to mountains, in forest and open areas.
Legally **Protected**. Population is widespread (IUCN: Least Concern).
European Fire-bellied Toad
Bombina bombina
Small toad known for its bright orange and black warning colors on its belly.
Widespread in the lowlands of central and eastern Poland, favoring shallow, warm waters.
Legally **Protected**. Found in high numbers in Natura 2000 sites (IUCN: Least Concern).
Grass Snake
Natrix natrix
The only non-venomous snake species in Poland, easily recognized by its yellow/white neck collar.
Widespread across all lowlands and lower mountains, always close to water sources.
Legally **Protected**. Population is stable (IUCN: Least Concern).
Common Roach
Rutilus rutilus
One of the most numerous and adaptable freshwater fish species in Europe.
Abundant in almost every type of water body: rivers, lakes, ponds, and reservoirs across Poland.
Common. Subject to fishing regulations (IUCN: Least Concern).
Common Bream
Abramis brama
A large, deep-bodied fish common in slow-moving waters and lakes.
Very common in all major river systems and lowland lakes throughout Poland.
Common. Subject to fishing regulations (IUCN: Least Concern).
European Perch
Perca fluviatilis
A predatory fish known for its striped body and two dorsal fins.
Widespread and common in clean rivers, lakes, and ponds across the entire country.
Common. Subject to fishing regulations (IUCN: Least Concern).
